element_texts.text:
November
I don’t know why I’m writing this.  There’s no real reason.  I’m thinking “Maybe he won’t even get to read it”.  But I feel like getting something off my chest.  It’s like when you hear a swell lecture and you want to tell the lecturer that he put it over swell.  Here’s how it started.  I am a student in Brooklyn College of The City of New York (a small place despite the long name) and am taking a course in The Modern English and American novel.  I had read very little previous to my enrollment in The course.  I knew of men like Lewis, Dreiser and Hemingway only because their stories were popularized into motion pictures.  I never heard of Sherwood Anderson.  One day in class, our instruction, while criticizing a certain author, drew an analogy.  She said something like this.”I felt that way when I read a book of Sherwood Anderson-I felt like opening the windows “ — She didn’t mention the book.  Incidentally, she is a Ph.D.  But, there’s something wrong with her, I think.  She needs either a faith or a

husband.  —-Well, after that I started thinking of what she said.  —“This guy Anderson must be pretty dirty or something-or else the teacher must be an awful prude.”  There are many large stores in New York.  The largest is Macy’s.  Sometimes I wander about the store viewing exhibits.  This day a sale was in progress on Modern Library books.  I looked over a few.  Prominent names.  Many people were surging around the counters.  Some called out their choice - I heard “Sons and Lovers” and “Anna Karenina” - I picked up a book.  It was entitled “Winesburg, Ohio”.  The name Anderson sounded vaguely familiar.  Oh yes!  I once caddied for a man by that name.  He was a great golfer and a nice chap (There was invariably a 50 cent tip.). I bought the book on a hunch.  I went home and read it.  It was swell - honest!  I re read it and had my friends read it - including my dentist.  They all enjoyed it.  “Doc” thought that story “Hands” was a masterpiece.  But I felt the surge of the stories more keenly.  Maybe I felt that way because I lived one half of my 20 years in a small town.  Those tales hit home.  They were genuine.  I thought of Monticello, N.Y.

II. Then I thought of my teacher.  God! what horror that a Ph.D. Should so speak- I thought that she had to open the windows because of the stench in her own mind.  Ph.D - bah!  Because I couldn’t see anything wrong with.  All I saw was honesty in the portrayal of the vices and virtues of those people.  And if brutal things were exposed, they sparkled with a human, healthy cleanliness.  Everyone in the class had to give an oral report on a novelist.  I spoke about you - as “representation of American Life”. I told the class about Winesburg- Poor white - Dark Laughter. I read excerpts.  Some were pretty raw for a co-ed class.  But I let them have it. I put it across swell.  I sat down.  The teacher had to admit the report was good but she added “I think you overestimate his ideas”  Then I knew he needed a husband more than a faith.  — Right now I’m reading “Story Teller’s story” and I feel like kicking myself.  Because all your idea are there and I should have read that book before I gave my report.

I like the way you write.  It’s so simple that it makes me admire and swear.  “Everything is said so simply - why anyone ought to be able to write like this”  It was like I was looking at an apple and you’d say “Here is an apple.  It is red” - and there it would be.  “Wouldn’t it be swell”, I thought, “if I could write like that?”  I copied pages and pages of your stuff.  Then I wrote an essay for my writing course.  I thought it was good.  My instructor had her own ideas.  My paper was returned with innumerable red decorations.  And I had ended it peculiarly, like you do when you say “could what?” (end of chapter in Dark Laughter) well.  The class tore me to pieces on the ending.  It was funny.  Me a plagiarist!  Then I realized that you’ve got to be yourself.  You know, somehow or other, college stunts your natural ability.  They don’t let you round out naturally.  They dress you up in a new suit of clothes- but when you look in the mirror you see your collar is too long or the tie is crooked or something else is mangled. Well.  That’s all there is.  There’s nothing for you to do.  Just tear the letter up.  I guess.  I just felt as if I ought to write you.  I don’t know why exactly.

III.  I got your address out of 1933 “Who’s Who in America “ - you occupy rather modest space: - name - date of birth - books written, editor, home Marion, Va.  We have a book in our library “Modern American Living Authors “  Your photo looks pretty good in it.  Please don’t think I’m writing this just to be effusive - or to ask for an autograph, etc.  No, sir.  It’s just an impulse and I ask you to pardon any outbursts of familiarity (But then again, why should you pardon me - did I do anything wrong)?  If you get a chance, why not answer?  I don’t want you to go out of your way.  But, I sure would like to read a letter from you to the class.  Even if it just says “Received yours of the —“ Thanx!  I’m writing an essay on your prose works.  Want to read it whenI get finished?  Norman Rosenstein 2930 West 19 St Brooklyn, N.Y.

March, 1934  I did something like this once before.  It was quite some time ago in a classroom at Brooklyn College in New York City where I was taking a course in “The Modern Novel”.  The discussion that day was on Sherwood Anderson.  I had just finished giving a report on this author and the instructress seemed to resent my too-complimentary remarks.  I delivered a damn good report, I tell you!  But this Ph.D. mam, in desperate need of either a faith or a man, makes this comment:  “He is ignorant and sentimental “.  Just like that!  It is not to soothe you that I say the entire class was disgusted.  But it is an old college custom that an “A” is worth thinking as the teacher does.  So nobody answers this but I know what they think.  I see them after class and we talk plenty!  But after class she says to me “So you’re in with that crowd too?”  I thought “I’d rather be in with anyone than be in a fog like you “ - I said “Sure!” So we argued and I challenged her to pick out a passage from “Winesburg” that betrays you and she comes around to the fact that you write nicely but too much about certain people and their environment and why all the sex and the report was good…

Well- now I want to tell you what it was I did before.  You have to know that because I start my letter with that intimation. Here’s what I did.  I wrote you a letter about the classroom scene.  A very charming letter.  You said so when you answered me. You also spoke about the attitude of certain readers - “like a bad smell, it only lingers in holes and sewers “.  I showed your letter to the teacher.  The handwriting annoyed her but the contents brought a smile.  She liked it and said “That will be worth something some day.  Hold on to it”. That’s what she said and I felt like taking a swing at her.  You know why.  But that has nothing to do with what I want to say.  I was going to speak of something else.  I don’t know how to start.  It’s like going up to a stranger and asking for a loan.  Or asking a lawyer’s advice over the phone.  See, it’s this way.  An encouraging remark in your letter (for which I thank you) plus the fact that Aristotle defines art as imitation, fanned in me a somewhat latent desire to write things.  And its a funny thing how I acted.  Sometimes I felt that all I could ever do was get a job.  I still think that.  But at times I get a strange feeling that I could write on miles of paper.  I get these

2 swell ideas in my head but when it comes to writing them down, nothing comes of it.  I guess it’s that way with everybody at times.  I live 500 yards from the Atlantic Ocean and I take walks often on the beach at night.  I try to feel myself into something or have something feel itself into me.  I never have a pencil when I think of something - and if I did have one, would I get something out of it?  —But, I’ll stop this talk because I feel like there’s so much I can say that I’ll only fall all over myself saying things.  And beside, why should I pick on you?  I have no right to annoy a respectable citizen.  You might be thinking “Just because I sent this guy a letter- does he think I have nothing else to do but read his mail?”  I once read an article of yours in October 1930 “Mercury “ in which a woman seemed to cause you great discomfort by continually sending you manuscripts to look over.  Now I’ll bet you are suspicious of the enclosed matter.  But, honest, it’s not that I want to bother you - It’s just that I thought, perhaps, when and if, time irks you, you might look over these short stories (3). There! now I said it.  I didn’t like to say it but I knew all along I’d have to.  If you’re

busy or not inclined to waste your time, just return the enclosed in the return-envelope. I guess they're not much good anyway. But if you could say so yourself, it would be more valuable than any criticism I can get in school. Or do you think I ought to take up medicine or dentistry? I wish I could let you know how much I value or, rather, would value your advice - even if it is one word or so. That's on the level..
I would send you money but I don't know much about what to send or say or expect. I never spoke to anyone or asked anybody about these things - you know what I mean. Maybe I'm breaking a code or something by doing this. But as George Moore said "Rules are made if it is only for the sake of breaking them - just as women are dressed if only for the pleasure of undressing them." This Moore - he can write sometimes -
Very Gratefully Yours,
Norman Rosenstein
P.S> Do you advise attempts at publication? If so, where? If not, don't be afraid to be brutal.

P.S.
I am reading your "Death in the Woods". I bought it for $1.00 and I got a swell buy. The fact is that you put out a delicious variety of stories in that volume! Some of them are gems. I read all of your stuff except "Mid American Chants" and "Window McPherson's Son". These are hard to get, it seems. I'm not writing anything to flatter you. That's not in my lines. I'm just telling you things. For instance, I am taking a course in Continental Fiction under a certain Dr. Harry Slochower - who has written some books on German Literature. Well, in this course, we study some of the big shots in Europe - Thomas Mann, Boibusse, Proust, Nero, Franz Verfel, Hansen, Gide, France, Dosteisvski, etc. In our syllabus of readings, he has included only two Americans: John Dos Passes "1919" and Sherwood Anderson "Beyond Desire". This teacher is good. He gives us new slants on interpretation: economic, etc. He circulated petitions about the play in New York "Peace on Earth". It was a terrific play. We all saw it. He's all there - this teacher.
I think this fellow Aristotle was a little lopsided when he said all art is imitation. I try

my damndest to imitate you. I see it's not as easy as it looks. When I try hard and mess things up - I get a lot of new respect for you. That's a fact! My friends are beginning to call me "Sherwood". Well, I don't feel any too bad about that, believe me!
And some of the teachers say "Sure, there moderns can write, but will you hear of them 100 years from now, take Shakespeare and Dante, for instance ---" But its not how long people "live" but what they say when they're alive! Take Faulkner's "Sound and the Fury" or Hemingway's stories ---
You hear funny things at school. Sometimes you don't know what to believe. I tell you, sometimes I think college is a waste of time! How the majority of the faculty love antiquity!
Well - this is enough. If I say too much, its just because I want to tell you things. That's all!!---
N. R.

Mr. Sherwood Anderson -
I have written to you before. Ordinary letters - asking for advice and such things. Once I even sent you some short stories and you were kind enough to read them. That was some time ago. Since then I have written better stuff and am somewhat ashamed of what I sent to you. I am a little better now, am getting some encouragement from people, from editors.
This letter is a little different. It scared me, just to think of writing it. But why should I be afraid?
I have been afraid too many times and now I will quit it.
Recently I read your article in "Today" magazine. I don't care for the magazine much, it's policy. It's like somebody trying to hold something up that's creaking pretty bad.
Of course, I read your books before this, nearly all of them (except this Mid-American Chants).
But this article - coming

back to it.  It made me think about it.  I remember reading that you wrote your first "novel" when you were about 40 years of age.  Then I thought, that was about 18 years ago.   I figured out you're near 60 now, close to it anyway.  Well, you're getting along in years.  At your age, anything can happen.  You might die.  I hope you do not for some time  But you might.  And that's why I'm writing.  Because I want to tell you, to let you know what your writing means to me.  I think to myself (half humorously, let's say) that I would like to write.  I am pretty young, 21.  So far my short stories and poems are excellent only for my college publications.  I have higher hopes.

Maybe I'll get there.  My dad says "Better look up a rich girl in case you get kicked out of here."  He's joking of course.  It takes me long to get to the point.  But I say this to you: that of all the prose I have digested, of all the books I have read, your writing always shines out above the others.  And believe me, I have read a lot.  At college, one has to read a lot.  And I still say the same thing year after year: that when I reread a piece of your writings, it leaves me feeling that I have read something!  Sometimes I discuss you with a teacher.  One said "I like his earlier work the best."  But as for me, I've told you.  I write articles, essays for the college paper.  And I find some

strange touch creeping into my prose that I absorbed from you.  It was almost unconscious.  It gave me a freedom that makes me write easier.  When I hit off a good article, I say to myself someone helped me.  Only people who can't feel into a man's writing will not know this.  
That's why I want to sort of thank you.  Even if I never get anywhere in the writing game (I think so often) I still say that I owe you a compliment, a thanks for the guidance your prose has given me.
Why should I be ashamed to tell you this?  I am honest, I know that.
Once I even stopped a pretty girl I had never met and told her "Lord!  But you are beautiful."
What the hell do I care if she thinks I am mad?
Sincerely 
Norman Rosenstein 
2930 West 19 St
Brooklyn, N.Y.

From Bernard Shaw. [letterhead]
I am afraid I can do nothing; for though I am doubtless persona grata in some official quarters I am very much the reverse in others; and my interference might do more harm than good.  You have done all that can be done; and as there can be no objection except the purely numerical one on the American side I presume it will lapse when your lady's turn comes.  I am sorry that this is all I can say.
Signature

4-6-32
1180 West 29 St.
Pr 7705 or Ri 4630
My Dear Mr. Anderson
This is a "I know you letter."  Some thirty five or so years ago my name was Vil Grimes & I lived in Clyde Ohio & I lived with my Grandmother Mrs. Bush who was also the Grandmother of "Bill" Thorpe a badly paralized [sic] boy.  We lived on Duane St. next to one of your hangout the Vogt Bros.  I remember you coming to see there also my brother John Grimes.  When your brother Carl [sic]

went to New York he sent "Bill" a pastel he did also I remember he used to print his letters to "Bill" instead of writing them as Bill would not read writing not being able to write with his hands.
So far as I know my sister Gertrude has these things among her many family possitions [sic].
I have often thot [sic] of writing you but that you must have a lot of people writing "I know you letters."  
But the memory of Clyde has always has unclear in my mind & I remember so many things about the g---- town & I have always enjoyed your writings about the place.  Your story tellers story is one of my daughters most prized books.  
I should very much like to hear you speak white you are here & if you care to let me know by phone I should love to just catch a glimpse of you &

if I could a few words.  I assure you Sherwood I am not a poky old lady.  Your brother Carl was in my room at school and how well I remember him with his tongue unclear his cheek every minute he was drawing.  We always thot [sic] his Xmas black board decorations were wonderful.  Now if you could find time out of one of your very busy days I should be more than pleased to see you.  
Sincerely yours
Vil Grimes Rummell

July 25 - 1924
Dear Sherwood -
I was about to write you that we had heard you were in town & that we were destroyed with grief entirely at not seeing you.  Well -- next time stay more than one day & come out.  Or if you cannot possibly do that call us up -- P.P. 39M1 -- & we will gladly rush in to see you.  
And your wife -- we want to hear about her.  Will you give her our very best wishes & a piece of the love we always have for you?  
We'll send the books along as soon as we can get them ready.  It's lovely to think of you settled in New Orleans.  We are anxious to come down & even think we might manage it during the winter.  How are living expenses there?  Anywhere near our capacity?  
You should see our infants now.  Barbara is a very big girl & Harriet is nearly three.  Felice is still the rascal of the lot, tall for

her age & thin & full of mischief.  She loves poetry.  Not that that's a logical consequence of mischievousness!  She just does.  Babs has done some very nice watercolors -- childish, of course, as they should be-- but lovely in color & pattern.  Felix is quite delighted with them & preserves them carefully.  
How I wish we had known you were to be in the city.  We should certainly have gone in if we could have seen you for only a moment.  Do let us know the next time, will you?  
One of those old evenings -- you reading a story or a poem from your Bible.  Do you remember them?  We certainly shall never forget -- they meant a great deal to us.  
I think my mind is shaping round for work again.  I haven't had a chance to do anything or had even a scrap of gray matter for so long, that it is a constant astonishment & joy to me to find ideas in my head.  
Felix is working like a slave -- one of his "periods" of inspiration.  He is painting quite differently now -- I'd like you to see

his latest things.  They are finer in technique & more abstract -- lovely things, & only a start toward what he has in mind.  Financially he begins to see a little ahead now -- not that we have any money yet -- & that means so much to him in peace of mind.  You know!  
Our house in Palos has gone by the board.  They are putting restrictions now if you please on the size & manner of house constructed in this village.  Nothing short of a small castle, costing at the least $8000 will suffice.  So we shall continue to drift -- and if we drift to New Orleans will you give us a welcoming hand & show us the sights -- & have some more evenings?  
We are of course much interested in the new novel & shall watch for it.  We read your story in the Feb (?) Mercury & liked it very much.  
We all send you a great deal of love & wish you both all the happiness in the world.  
As ever 
Helen
in different handwriting:
Russmann

April 12 - 1925
Dear Sherwood --
If you come to see us now you'll come to a new place.  We are even now in the act of moving from our present domicile to the house the Smiths used to live in.  We are painting and scrubbing and sweating to make it a cheerful and a lovely place and I think we are going to like it very much.  We're making all the floors reed -- maroon.  The Smiths are buying the white cottage -- across from Mary's -- down in the field.  Kemley has become a golf fiend and plays every week-end.  
Tennessee writes us that there is some misunderstanding about the books.  If any are missing I am the only one responsible, because I did all the shipping back of both sets of books myself.

I have here a [Dostoevsky] of yours and there is missing your copy of Mid American Chants which disappeared as mysteriously as my own copy of Winesburg, & which I have been hoping against hope would appear again.  We must have some friend fond even unto stealing of your works!  At any rate I intend of course to replace the book if it does not turn up.  I am quite positive the others were returned to you -- some, you remember, to New York while you were there.  The two volumes of The Seven Arts were sent to New York as well.  Have you the list which I returned to you?  I never worked off anything that was not packed to send, under my own eye.  As soon as I can locate things in the mess I'll look up my own list and se if I can't straighten it out.  If any are really gone I'll feel very miserable about it and of course I'll make it good.  If only unclear not first editions!

Palos Park, Ill.
Sept. 18, 1925
Dear Sherwood -
Darn your Dark Laughter!  I thought I had just damped down a lot of thoughts that have been tormenting me lately & now you've gone & blown them to a flame again.
My whole outlook on life seems to be undergoing a change.  I was for so many years concerned too deeply with myself & my problems, for life in general to be much more than shadowy to me.  Now I am about overwhelmed with realizations that life is cruel, chaotic, wonderful, beyond all belief.  And I am wildly trying to find a good solid rock to plant myself in; one that won't do more than shake a little in the earthquakes.

One of the things that is slowly coming home to me is the appalling selfishness that exists in so many people -- a ruthless selfishness that walks over everything.  I never used to believe it -- I am being made to believe it.  And it's a little disrupting.
I would give a good deal to talk to you about your book.  I realize though that you have said there what you have to say & that I'll have to puzzle through to my own solution & my own expression, if I can reach that far.  
But suppose Aline had really loved her husband & not Bruce at all?  Couldn't it all have happened just the same?  And then what would they have done?  
Just how important, after all, are out bodies?  I resent mine, sometimes

sometimes -- I would rather live in the wind.  But there you are -- I love a body.
Your book is wonderful, Sherwood.  I can't begin to tell you how much it means to me.  It's a little piece out of life -- with all the undertones.  And I'm sending you a little clipping I found one day that pleased me very much -- perhaps you haven't seen it.  
Your talk of floating down the River in a boat certainly fired Felix.  I'm sure that if you want a companion on that trip all you'll have to do is waggle a finger.  I'm interested in Elizabeth's shop -- I'm thinking of having a Christmas season shop myself -- for works de art executed by Felix & myself.  What kind is hers?  
Write us what you are doing down there.  I wish we could come down.
Love from us all -
Helen

1416 Florida St, Baton Rouge, La.
Tuesday -
Dear Sherwood, 
Well, bless your heart!  Your letter and Mr. Liveright's came in the same mail yesterday, and this afternoon I mailed him the two stories that you read -- clean copies, however.  It was damn decent of you to do this for me -- and it means a lot, as you know.  I'm trying so hard to do something real in my book: and I've been working steadily since I saw you last.  I should be finished before Christmas -- and then New York, I hope, for a time . . . It may be that I can see you then.  I hope so.

write too much about it.  I wish you could introduce some of those reviewers to Don Wright.  Why, I sat and listened to a story of sex-motivation (his own story) all night long one night at The Monteleone.  He evaded us by saying that he was done with it all; he was "free" and was going to New Mexico.  The next news I received was yesterday's letter, from Chicago!  
Elizabeth was fine when I saw her last, although a little blue over you going, I thought.  All of which was natural enough.  I hope to see her soon again, as I must go to New Orleans on business next week.  It's great to hear that your lectures are going over so well.  The best of luck to you -- and thank you again.  I'll try to live up to the reputation that Liveright says you give me.  
As usual 
Lyle Saxon

Please give my greetings to Anita Loos.  I did enjoy meeting her that day at the Green Shutter when we all sat and talked of Al. Jackson and his exploits.  I liked the way she laughed.  Odd, isn't it, how few people know how to laugh?  
And that brings me to Dark Laughter -- I'm delighted to hear it's going so well.  Surely, it deserves to go if a book ever did!  And what excellent reviews!  I see them everywhere.  I don't think I told you how much I liked the nigger parts.  It's the real thing.  
I had a note from Donald Wright.  He went back to Chicago -- after leaving New Orleans headed for Santa Fe!  God knows!  And still they tell us, Sherwood, that we think too much about sex!  Or rather they insist that you

March 3, 1926
Dear Sherwood, 
I thought I was hard boiled, but tears came into my eyes when I read your note just now.  Lately I've been thinking myself a failure; but your kindness is writing what you did about "Cane River" made me happy.  
I can't say what I would like to say, and perhaps I never can; but I think you know that I'd rather have your praise than that of any other man in the world.
Your friend,
Lyle Saxon.

What a reference to our snowy wash down by my beautiful unclear whom Sherwood once met!
Love from
Clara
Men are like that!

[Letterhead:
Hotel Flamingo
5520 South Shore Drive
Chicago, Illinois]
April 27, 30
Dear Sherwood, 
This Loom Dance, it's marvelous!  I do not remember that you have never done a more real, a more imaginative thing.  Your art is getting subtler with every year, carries a richer harmony of over-tones.  How do you do it?  Do you call this a short story?  Well,

2
[Letterhead:
Hotel Flamingo
5520 South Shore Drive
Chicago, Illinois]
it has got enclosed in its circumference a dance, a poem, an ethical discussion?, and an allegory of the modern world.  How are you and where are you?  Clara's a my love go out to you.  Clara was the first to find and praise this newest jewel of your cutting.  Things must be better with you that they were. 
Ferdinand.
